sources.data_found: Hummingbird cluster: 1 GPU node with 4 GPUs (96x24gpu4); 512 AMD EPYC cores (8 nodes x 64 cores each) with 4TB RAM total; BeeGFS parallel file system with ~750TB storage connected at 200Gbps Infiniband
Hyades supercomputer: 376 Intel Sandy Bridge Xeon CPUs (3008 cores total), 8 Nvidia K20 GPU computing accelerators, 3 Intel Xeon Phi 5110P accelerators, 13TB memory, peak speed 60 TFLOPS
UC Santa Cruz Center for Coastal Climate Resilience: cluster of 4 NVIDIA RTX 6000 Ada Generation GPUs for flood modeling
In 2023, the most popular Bachelors Degree concentrations at UC Santa Cruz were Computer Science (658 degrees awarded); Total enrollment 19,764 students (17,812 undergraduate, 1,952 graduate)

student_data.notes: CS undergraduate count estimated from: 658 CS bachelor's degrees awarded in 2023 (DataUSA) × 4 years = 2,632 steady-state enrollment. Graduate CS count estimated based on typical MS/PhD program proportions at UC campuses, with MS students representing ~70% of graduate CS enrollment (350 MS) and PhD students ~30% (150 PhD), totaling 500 graduate CS students.

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: Hyades cluster has 8 Nvidia K20 GPU computing accelerators (older generation, Tesla K20)
UC Santa Cruz Center for Coastal Climate Resilience has cluster of 4 RTX 6000 Ada GPUs
Hummingbird has 1 GPU node with 4 GPUs (model not specified in sources)
Elkhorn (coming early 2026) will have 8 GPUs (model not specified)
Access to Nautilus distributed cluster with Quadro, RTX, L40/L40s, A10, A100, and Tesla GPUs (shared national resource, not UCSC-owned)

gpu_resources.notes:
CLUSTERS IDENTIFIED:

1) Hyades (2013): 8 × NVIDIA K20 GPUs (older Tesla architecture)

2) Hummingbird: 1 GPU node with 4 GPUs (model unspecified)

3) UC Santa Cruz Coastal Center: 4 × RTX 6000 Ada GPUs (counted as A6000)

4) Elkhorn (coming 2026): 8 GPUs planned (model unspecified)

5) Nautilus/NRP: Shared national resource, not UCSC-owned

NOTE: UC Santa Cruz appears to have limited modern GPU infrastructure compared to peer UC campuses. Most identified GPUs are older generation (K20) or unspecified models. No H100, H200, A100, or other current-generation datacenter GPUs were found in UCSC-owned clusters.

analysis_notes: UC Santa Cruz has relatively modest GPU resources, with most being older generation (K20 from 2013) or specialized for specific research (RTX 6000 Ada for coastal modeling). The university relies heavily on shared resources like Nautilus/NRP for modern GPU access.
